dataIdInfo.idAbs: Calculates the maximum upstream elevation for each input cell on an elevation raster.

tool.name: MaximumUpstreamElevation

param.name: in_flow_direction_raster
param.dialogReference:
The input raster that shows the direction of flow out of each cell.

A flow direction raster can be generated by first using the Flow Direction tool on the input surface raster.
param.pythonReference:
The input raster that shows the direction of flow out of each cell.

A flow direction raster can be generated by first using the Flow Direction tool on the input surface raster.

param.name: out_raster
param.dialogReference: The output raster whose cell values contain the highest upstream elevation along the longest upstream flow path.
param.pythonReference: The output raster whose cell values contain the highest upstream elevation along the longest upstream flow path.

tool.summary: Calculates the maximum upstream elevation for each input cell on an elevation raster.
tool.usage:
• This tool requires a Spatial Analyst license.

  • The cell value on the output raster identifies the elevation of the origin of the stream that flows through the cell.

  • The input flow direction raster can be generated with the Flow Directiontool.

  • The following environment settings affect this tool:

    • General: Current Workspace, Scratch Workspace, Output Coordinate System, Output Extent, Snap Raster.

    • Raster Analysis: Cell Size, Mask.

scriptExample.title: MaximumUpstreamElevation example (Python window)
scriptExample.para: This example calculates the maximum upsteam elevation for an input elevation raster and save it as an Esri Grid.
scriptExample.code:
#Add toolbox to arcpy arcpy.AddToolbox(r"C:\pythontoolbox\Spatial Analyst Supplemental Tools.pyt")
#Execute MaximumUpstreamElevation tool arcpy.MaximumUpstreamElevation_sas(r'C:\ToolData\elevation', r'C:\ToolData\flowdir', r"c:\temp\maxelev1")

scriptExample.title: MaximumUpstreamElevation example (Stand-alone script)
scriptExample.para: This example calculates the maximum upsteam elevation for an input elevation raster and save it as an Esri Grid.
scriptExample.code:
#Add toolbox to arcpy arcpy.AddToolbox(r"C:\pythontoolbox\Spatial Analyst Supplemental Tools.pyt") arcpy.CheckOutExtension("spatial")
inElevation = r'C:\ToolData\elevation' inFlowDir = r'C:\ToolData\flowdir' outRaster = r"c:\temp\maxelev1"
#Execute MaximumUpstreamElevation tool arcpy.MaximumUpstreamElevation_sas(inElevation, inFlowDir, outRaster)
